title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the region of the United States that uses the highest percent of incandescent lightbulbs for residential lighting per household as Southeastern Central.
The response identifies the region of the United States that uses the highest percent of incandescent lightbulbs for residential lighting per household as Southeastern Central.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the approximate difference in the percent of incandescent light bulbs per household in the South Atlantic region from the United States average as 2% to 3% higher than the United States average.

The response identifies the approximate difference in the percent of incandescent light bulbs per household in the South Atlantic region from the United States average as 2% to 3% higher than the United States average.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the region of the United States that is closest to the national average of percent of households that have 40 or more light bulbs as Middle Atlantic.
The response identifies the region of the United States that is closest to the national average of percent of households that have 40 or more light bulbs as Middle Atlantic.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why a power company would choose wind energy rather than solar energy to replace electricity generation by fossil fuels, such as any of the following:

· Wind energy can generate power 24 hours a day while solar panels can generate power only during daylight hours, so they provide a potentially more continuous source of power than solar panels.

· The power company would consider availability of sunlight vs. wind in a local climate, so in areas where wind is a more consistent source of energy than sunlight, wind energy would provide a more consistent power supply.

· The initial investment for wind energy is lower because wind energy turbine production and installation is less expensive than solar panel production and installation in many cases based on the materials needed to construct a solar panel.

· The power company would need to acquire less land for wind turbines than solar energy farms, which require a large area to collect sunlight.

· Wind energy is more efficient than solar energy because the conversion rate for solar panels is low compared to a wind turbine.

The response explains why a power company would choose wind energy rather than solar energy to replace electricity generation by fossil fuels, such as one of the following:

· Wind energy can generate power 24 hours a day while solar panels can generate power only during daylight hours, so they provide a potentially more continuous source of power than solar panels.

· The power company would consider availability of sunlight vs. wind in a local climate, so in areas where wind is a more consistent source of energy than sunlight, wind energy would provide a more consistent power supply.

· The initial investment for wind energy is lower because wind energy turbine production and installation is less expensive than solar panel production and installation in many cases based on the materials needed to construct a solar panel.

· The power company would need to acquire less land for wind turbines than solar energy farms, which require a large area to collect sunlight.

· Wind energy is more efficient than solar energy because the conversion rate for solar panels is low compared to a wind turbine.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem associated with the renewable energy source that until 2019 was the largest contributor to electricity generation in the United States, such as any of the following:

· Hydroelectric dams disrupt fish migrations which can reduce spawning/reduce fish reproduction.

· Turbines in hydroelectric dams kill fish, decreasing fish populations/biodiversity.

· Hydroelectric dams disrupt local ecosystem biodiversity/aquatic food chains because there is a physical barrier preventing movement of organisms.

· Hydroelectric dams increase sediment deposition in the river upstream of the dam and decrease sediment deposition downstream of the dam, which can lead to habitat loss/water-borne diseases.

· Hydroelectric dams decrease rate of nutrient renewal, which affects aquatic ecosystems.

The response describes one environmental problem associated with the renewable energy source that until 2019 was the largest contributor to electricity generation in the United States, such as one of the following:

· Hydroelectric dams disrupt fish migrations which can reduce spawning/reduce fish reproduction.

· Turbines in hydroelectric dams kill fish, decreasing fish populations/biodiversity.

· Hydroelectric dams disrupt local ecosystem biodiversity/aquatic food chains because there is a physical barrier preventing movement of organisms.

· Hydroelectric dams increase sediment deposition in the river upstream of the dam and decrease sediment deposition downstream of the dam, which can lead to habitat loss/water-borne diseases.

· Hydroelectric dams decrease rate of nutrient renewal, which affects aquatic ecosystems.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that proposes a reasonable solution to the problem identified in part (f), such as any of the following:

Hydroelectric dams disrupt fish migrations and can reduce spawning/reduce fish reproduction or hydroelectric dams disrupt local ecosystem biodiversity/aquatic food chains because there is a physical barrier preventing movement of organisms (problem in part (f)).

· Install fish ladders/other methods of fish passage so that fish species can move upstream of the dam

· Dam removal to restore the free flow of the river, with replacement with another source of energy (microhydro/run of river/other renewable sources)

Hydroelectric dams increase sediment upstream (problem in part (f)).

· Remove sediment from reservoirs behind dams and release downstream

Hydroelectric dams decrease sediment deposition downstream, which can lead to habitat loss/water-borne diseases (problem in part (f)).

· Remove sediment from reservoirs behind dams and release downstream

· Schedule periodic releases to restore sediment deposition downstream

Hydroelectric dams decrease rate of nutrient renewal, which affects aquatic ecosystems (problem in part (f)).

· Remove sediment from reservoirs behind dams and release downstream

Hydroelectric dams impact cultural resources and infrastructure of landscape when reservoir fills (problem in part (f)).

· Watershed management strategies (soil conservation, catchment restoration, dredging, etc.) to reduce impact of reservoir on land upstream from dam

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a disadvantage or unintended consequence of the solution proposed in part (g), such as any of the following:

Install fish ladders so that fish species can move upstream of the dam (solution in part (g)).

· It is expensive to install fish ladders.

· It can be difficult for fish to climb the ladder/it can be physically exhausting for fish to migrate even using the ladder.

· Fish ladders can concentrate the number of fish in a given area increasing predation on migrating fish by predators.

Remove sediment from reservoirs behind dams and release downstream (solution in part (g)).

· It is expensive to remove the sediment.

· Dredging the reservoir disturbs the bottom habitat/disrupts species that live or feed or lay eggs in the sediment.

· Dredging releases trapped pollutants/metals that can move downstream.

Watershed management strategies (soil conservation, catchment restoration, dredging, etc.) to reduce impact of reservoir on land upstream from dam (solution in part (g)).

· Watershed management must incorporate a variety of land uses in some regions.

· Remediation/management strategies can be costly to implement May not be most profitable use of the land in urban areas.

The response describes a disadvantage or unintended consequence of the solution proposed in part (g), such as one of the following:

Install fish ladders so that fish species can move upstream of the dam (solution in part (g)).

· It is expensive to install fish ladders.

· It can be difficult for fish to climb the ladder/it can be physically exhausting for fish to migrate even using the ladder.

· Fish ladders can concentrate the number of fish in a given area increasing predation on migrating fish by predators.

Remove sediment from reservoirs behind dams and release downstream (solution in part (g)).

· It is expensive to remove the sediment.

· Dredging the reservoir disturbs the bottom habitat/disrupts species that live or feed or lay eggs in the sediment.

· Dredging releases trapped pollutants/metals that can move downstream.

Watershed management strategies (soil conservation, catchment restoration, dredging, etc.) to reduce impact of reservoir on land upstream from dam (solution in part (g)).

· Watershed management must incorporate a variety of land uses in some regions.

· Remediation/management strategies can be costly to implement May not be most profitable use of the land in urban areas.
